question.title: Making HTML table borders collapse in Java 8
question.body:
How do I ensure my JLabel's HTML table borders collapse? border-collapse doesn't work.

import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JOptionPane;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.WindowConstants;
import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import java.awt.Component;
import java.awt.Container;

public class JOptionPaneDemo {

    static JFrame frame;

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        frame = new JFrame("HTML Message Demo");
        frame.setContentPane(createMainPanel());
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        frame.pack();
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    private static Container createMainPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel(new BorderLayout());
        panel.add(createHtmlMessageButton());
        return panel;
    }

    private static Component createHtmlMessageButton() {
        JButton button = new JButton("Show message");
        button.addActionListener(e -> showMessage());
        return button;
    }

    private static void showMessage() {
        JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(frame, createMessage(), "HTML message", JOptionPane.INFORMATION_MESSAGE);
    }

    private static String createMessage()
        String message = "<html><head><style>table {border-collapse: collapse;} td {border: 1px solid;} </style></head>" +
                "<body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td><tr></table></body></html>";
        return message;
    }
}

I tried this workaround:

    private static String createMessage() {
        String message = "<html><head><style>table {border-bottom: 1px solid;border-right: 1px solid;} td {border-top: 1px solid;border-left: 1px solid;} </style></head>" +
                "<body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td><tr></table></body></html>";
        return message;
    }

but it still looks weird, albeit in a different way:

answers.body:
The second solution could be improved by setting border-spacing to zero

        String message = "<html><head><style>table {border-spacing: 0; border-bottom: 1px solid; border-right: 1px solid;} td {border-top: 1px solid;border-left: 1px solid;} </style></head>" +
                "<body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td><tr></table></body></html>";

This is purely HTML+CSS consideration.

Browser have usually default styles for some HTML elements. For table borwsers (at least on mine machine) defined border-spacing: 2px. Thus the problem.

As mentioned you could also use border-spacing: 0;, however it would mean that adjacent borders will add up to 2px border.

Additionally to that, you need to combine it with border-collapse: collapse;

**But as mentioned, Spring does not handle border-collapse, so I suggest following styles (explanations are inline)

<html>

<head>
  <style>
    table {
      border-spacing: 0;
    }

    td {
      border: 1px solid black;
      /* remove right border for all but last column */
      border-right: none;
      /* remove bottom border for all but last row */
      border-bottom: none;
    }

    tr td:last-child {
      /* restore right edge */
      border-right: 1px solid black;
    }

    tr:last-child td {
      /* restore bottom edge */
      border-bottom: 1px solid black;
    }
  </style>
</head>

<body>
  <table>
    <tr>
      <td>1</td>
      <td>2</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>3</td>
      <td>4</td>
    </tr>
  </table>

</body>

</html>

Here's your updated Java code:

private static String createMessage() {
    String message = "<html><head><style>table{border-spacing:0}td{border:1px solid #000;border-right:none;border-bottom:none}tr td:last-child{border-right:1px solid #000}tr:last-child td{border-bottom:1px solid #000}</style></head><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td></tr></table></body></html>";
    return message;
}

It doesn't work as well as my solution exactly because border-collapse is not supported by Swing's HTML. As a result, you get a bold border "cross" in the middle
